title: Why doesn’t gravity prevent the universe from continuing to expand? - Quora

response.answer_text: Inertia + Expansion = Gravity (Nov 7, 2017).1.pdf[1] The answer to the question as to why gravity does not prevent expansion was correctly answered by Carlos Santacruz, specifically “Gravity is caused by expansion” Other Quoran’s, including myself, have have posted similar statements. Without going into whether Santachez’s “The Empty Universe Theory” is correct or complete, the following explanation is proffered: Richard Feynman appears to be the first to suggest the possibility that gravity could be a pseudo force. Reasoning from the proposition that local g forces, like pseudo forces, are always proportional to the masses, “is it not possible that gravitation is due simply to the fact we do not have the right coordinate system?” Pseudo forces require a primary acceleration, and since gravity is, in general, a 3-d phenomena, one needs a 3-d source to create a 3-d reactionary field. Where might one find an isotropic 3-d acceleration field? We need not look far. Big G is everywhere - a universal three dimensional expansion field having dimensional units: “ cubic meters per second squared per kg” In words, the dimension units of big G are volumetric acceleration per unit mass (m^3/sec^2)/kg. Big G represents accelerating volume. But does it have the correct value to comport with what we now know to be the expansion rate of the universe? Ironically, it was Einstein that (regrettably) first proposed a cosmological constant (CC) to prevent gravitational collapse of his static model of the universe. He calculated the (CC) would have to have a value 3H^2, whence, when multiplied by R/3, the counter-field acceleration would have a value (CC)(R/3) = (3H^2)(R/3) = c^2/R. Net force would be zero if (CC) = 4(pi)G(p)………..(1) where p is the density But the above equation assumes that gravity and expansion are independent forces (Thought to be finely tuned to balance such that for most of the 20th century, it could not be determined which would win out {gravity or expansion}) The imagined hyperbole should have been resolved by the 1998 discovery that the universe was accelerating at the rate c^2/R just as Einstein had calculated 85 years earlier. But there was in reality no fine tuning except in the minds of the cosmologists that did not realize for 100 years that gravity is actually a consequence of expansion. To see this, simply use the above relationship (1) and solve for G. G = (CC)/4(pi)p =3H^2/4(pi)p This is simply Friedmann’s formulation. Now substitute M/(4/3)pi(R^3) for p and c/R for H, and find G = [c^2/R] x K where K is a constant [(m^2)/kg] x 1/4(pi)kg The cosmological expansion factor c^2/R is embedded in G.
